1. Nf3 f6 2. Nc3 Nh6 3. g4 c6 4. d4 e6 5. Ng5 f5 6. e4 Bd6 7. e5 g6

7 ... g6

8. Nb5

Black does not have fxg4 because of Nc7-Kf8-Qf3-Nf5-Bh6+.

8 ... cxb5 9. Bb5 Nc6

10. exd6

10 ... Kf8 11. Bxd7

8 ... Bb4+ 9. c3

9 ... cxb5

10. Qb3

Note that if black plays 10 ... fxg4, white wins with 11. Qb4 d6 12. Qb5+ Nc6 13. exd6+ (white's king is safe after Qh4-Kd1-Qg4-f3). But if black plays, say, 10 ... b5, white has the secondary threat 11. Qb4 d6 12. exd6 Qd6 13. Nxe6.

10 ... Nc6

11. Nxe6

11 ... d5 12. exd6

10 ... Qa5 11. Qb6

11 ... Qxb6 12. Nxh7

8 ... Na6

9. Nc7+ Kf8 10. b4

10 ... f4

11. h4

11 ... Nxg4

12. Bxf4

8 ... Kf8

9. Nc7

9 ... f4

10. h4

10 ... Nxg4

11. Bxf4

8 ... Ba3 9. Nc7+ Kf8 10. bxa3 Na6 11. c3

It does not help the case if black instead goes 8 ... Ba3 because it allows Nc7-Kf8. Now white can play 12. h4 with impunity.

8 ... Qa5+ 9. b4

9 ... fxg4

10. Nc7+

Black has to take on c7 to avoid Kf8-Qf3-Nf5-Ba6+.

10 ... Bxc7 11. bxa5
